Hello, thanks for the patch. All new APIs touching PLDM wire-format message buffers must be implemented in terms of the `msgbuf` APIs. This ensures the code maintains spatial memory safety, endian safety, and has reasonable performance. I've left comments in-line saying as much, along with others addressing a number of concerns.
Please avoid adding tabs after spaces. I think the indentation is unnecessary in this case, but if you disagree please use only spaces.
Done
Can we please not mark this as `__attribute__((packed))`? Given we have the codec functions nothing should be trying to cast this type over a wire-format buffer.

Please don't mark discussion threads as resolved unless we have reached consensus.

Yes, not marking as packed have that effect. This isn't surprising. The problem is using `sizeof()` derive the buffer size. Why must you do that?

My preferred strategy is to provide a #define` in the appropriate public header that provides the associated wire-format buffer size.

> Please don't mark discussion threads as resolved unless we have reached consensus.

Sure, I'll remember that, thanks.

I've removed the `__attribute__((packed))` keyword and replace it with a `#define`.
Done
Can we please not mark this as `__attribute__((packed))`? Given we have the codec functions nothing should be trying to cast this type over a wire-format buffer.
Please refer the reply above, thanks.
likewise.
Done, marked resolved since already removed it.
`I` shouldn't be capitalised here?
Done, thanks for reminding.
Can we please not mark this as `__attribute__((packed))`? Given we have the codec functions nothing should be trying to cast this type over a wire-format buffer.
Please refer the reply about `__attribute__((packed))` above, thanks.
likewise.
Done, marked resolved since already removed it.
I'd prefer we define this to be an enum type and do the conversion to the wire type internal to the implementation.
Done
Please reimplement this in terms of the `msgbuf` APIs.

If you're triggering an assert that indicates a buffer overrun then the calling code must be fixed. Either the buffer you supplied is too small, the `payload_length` value is incorrect, or you tried to pack too many members into the buffer for its size. This is not an error of the `msgbuf` APIs.
Done, refactored to msgbuf.
Done
This seems unexpected?
Done, my original thought is that the decoding is successful but the completion code of the response is not SUCCESS, I have changed it into an error code instead.

Here is a case: If the the completion code of the response is PLDM_ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD, the decode function would fail. However, I think it should be considered as SUCCESS and let the caller decide how to handle the completion code.

Yes, I think perhaps we need to disregard my concern for now. It's part of a broader problem of libpldm not separating the protocol command codes from library error codes.

However, please note the previous point about not marking discussion threads as resolved unless we've reached consensus.
Please reimplement this in terms of the `msgbuf` APIs.
Done
Can you please exercise all the error paths?
Done
Can you please exercise all of the error paths?
Done

Thanks for reviewing, I've modified the code based on the suggestion, but I encountered some difficulties about `msgbuf`, which cause the test case failed, it would be great if you can point out the root cause of the error, thank you so much.
Hello, I have some remaining concerns from PS4.
Hi, thanks for all the review comments, I've modified the code based on the suggestions, please let me know if there is any other suggestions.

Please remove `__attribute__((packed))`.

Please audit the rest of the patch for any such concerns.
Done
Hi, I have several comments inline. One of the more important is the memory safety risks identified, but there are others that require rework as well.

`NextDataTransferHandle` (`uint32`) and `TransferFlag` (`enum8`) are (at least) required in the response. In addition to `CompletionCode` this yields a minimum response size of (at least) 6 bytes. Why have you only counted `CompletionCode` here?

I found some cases which the response would contain only CC, in [DSP0240](https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0240_1.1.0.pdf):

> For an unsupported PLDM command, the ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD completion code shall be returned unless the responder is in a transient state (not ready), in which it cannot process the PLDM command. If the responder is in a transient state, it may return the ERROR_NOT_READY completion code.

Since this command is optional, the command handler might not be implemented in a device's firmware, after dig into the DSP0267, I didn't see `NextDataTransferHandle ` and `TransferFlag` are required if the CC is `ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD `, please let me know if I am wrong.

For instance, if a command receiver does not support this command, it won't know the existence of `NextDataTransferHandle` and `TransferFlag` but only response ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD, in my perspective, such response should be treated as Pass in the decode function.

I refactored the decode function to use `msgbuf`, AFAIK, I have to init the `msgbuf` before I access any data in the response msg, to fulfill the requirement above, I defined `PLDM_QUERY_DOWNSTREAM_IDENTIFIERS_RESP_MIN_LEN 1` to init the `msgbuf`.

Okay, with the comment you've added to the code I think this is reasonable. Thanks.

I'm wondering whether there's a better API design-point to handle these cases. I'll mull on that some more.

I defined a more generic macro `PLDM_OPTIONAL_COMMAND_RESP_MIN_LEN` can be used in any optional command, if it looks good to you, i can replace `PLDM_QUERY_DOWNSTREAM_IDENTIFIERS_RESP_MIN_LEN` with this one.

Link: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/70728/5/include/libpldm/firmware_update.h#33
Sounds good.

How did you derive the value 12 here?

`QueryDownstreamIdentifiers` has a complex response. I would really prefer that you add references to the relevant tables in a comment justifying the derivation.
Done, please review the comment I added, thanks.
Done
These are a part of table 17. I think I'd prefer we use a separate struct? Let's make the structure of the implementation match the structure of the spec.

I have some different thought about this, the name of Table 17 is `QueryDownstreamIdentifiers response definition`, and the description of the `Variable` in Table 16 is `Portion of QueryDownstreamIdentifiers response`, so I prefer to let it be squshed together.

Not like `DownstreamDevices` in Table 18, if we split them into 2 structs, the naming of the struct for Table 17 would become tricky because it is still a response of QueryDownstreamIdentifiers, do you have any suggestion for it?
Okay, that's probably fair. Perhaps the spec could combine table 16 and 17...

Can we please order this parameter after `struct pldm_msg *msg`? So:

```c
int encode_query_downstream_identifiers_req(
    uint8_t instance_id, uint32_t data_transfer_handle,
    enum transfer_op_flag transfer_operation_flag,
    struct pldm_msg *msg, size_t payload_length);
```

You'll also need to fix the ordering in the doxygen comment.
Done
How are we meant to write the decoded values through these pointers if the object they point to is declared to be const?

There is a new [commit](https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/66c7723adbdcc7594038167a78f3101a277021f7) to change pldm_msgbuf_extract() to accept a lvalue
> 1. `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` no-longer requires that the `dst`
   argument be a pointer. Instead, it must be an lvalue, removing all
   the `&<lvalue>` noise from the call-sites.

The const was revised by clang-tidy, but I think I have some misunderstanding about this change, use pldm_msgbuf_extract_p() instead and removed the `const`.

Dereferencing the pointer makes no sense for what you're trying to do. Use the `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p()` macro function, which requires a pointer argument. This applies to the next 3 calls below where you're currently dereferencing a pointer as well.
Done

I would prefer we don't open-code reaching into the msgbuf struct. Perhaps we should add something to the `msgbuf` API to allow this. Perhaps we add support for `struct variable_field` to `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p()`?
Also see `pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining()`.
And `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()`, which is what should be used here.

Done, thanks for reminding, these functions looks good. BTW, is there a doc to explain all available functions and its usage for `msgbuf`? Clearly I missed these good functions because I did not dig into the source code & tests for `msgbuf`, sorry for that.

This is problematic on a few fronts:

1. You haven't tested the result of `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` on line 1018 above to validate that you actually extracted a value at all. `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` will return an error if we've already exhausted the buffer (in which case no value will be extracted). You can only avoid testing the return value of `pldm_msgbuf_extract*()` if you _do not_ use the extract value in a subsequent computation inside the codec function.
2. `downstream_devices_length` has not been validated against the actual buffer length, and could allow the sender to drive an out-of-bounds memory access.

You must validate both - as it stands the implementation puts us on the receiving end of a CVE.

Sure, I've revised the code and added two test cases to test the failure of `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p` and `pldm_msgbuf_span_required`.

`decodeRequestErrorBufSize` tests the buff is exhausted during `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p`.

`decodeRequestErrorDownstreamDevicesSize` tests the incorrect length of DownstreamDevicesLength.
This is done, though see my comments above about where testing the return code of `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p()` is and is not necessary.
Hi, I've modified the code base on the suggestion, and improved the validation of buff exhausted issues, please review, thanks.
Hi, I have a couple of minor cleanup requests, but overall this is an improvement. Thanks!
This is good. Thanks.
The value of `next_data_transfer_handle` is not used below, we can remove this check
Done
The value of `transfer_flag` is not used below, we can remove this check
Done
This needs to be kept, because we dereference `downstream_devices_length` below in the call to `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()`.
Done
The value of `number_of_downstream_devices` is not used below, we can remove this check
Done
Hmm, is the cast necessary here?
Yes, the variable_field->ptr is a `const uint8_t*`, there will be a compilling error if don't do this. I saw the unit tests for `pldm_msgbuf_span_required` also do this castinig.
Mmm, okay. Again, if it starts to become too prevalent I'll consider making it a bit more ergonomic.
Hi, the code has been revised, and I have some suggestion for the response with only `CompletionCode`, please refer to the comment below, thanks!
Hello. This is starting to look good. Probably the main comment is regarding using the struct you defined for the decode API. I think that will improve the ergonomics.  Thanks for iterating!
We now have `PLDM_QUERY_DOWNSTREAM_IDENTIFIERS_RESP_MIN_LEN` from the prior patch so I think we can drop this? I don't think it's helpful any more.
Done
This is the response minimum length, maybe rename it to `PLDM_QUERY_DOWNSTREAM_IDENTIFIERS_RESP_MIN_LEN` now that we have dealt with the optional command problem?
Done

Okay, given we've sorted out some of the other issues, we can start honing in on the API. Rather than all of these individual parameters, why not take a pointer to `struct pldm_query_downstream_identifiers_resp`? So:

```
int decode_query_downstream_identifiers_resp(const struct pldm_msg *msg,
        size_t payload_length,
        struct pldm_query_downstream_identifiers_resp *resp,
        struct variable_field *downstream_devices);
```
Done, yeah, this is more concise, thanks.
Typo: `transfer`
Done
If this becomes a wider problem we should look at addressing it. I have ideas, but we don't need to do anything just yet.
Acknowledged

See comment on the header.

Note that if you make that change the `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p()` invocations below change back to `pldm_msgbuf_extract()`, as you pass the struct member lvalue.
Done
Can you add a comment about why we need `ASSERT_DEATH()`?

Originally, I use the return code to verify the result like this:
```
rc = decode_query_downstream_identifiers_resp(
                     response, responseMsg.size() - hdrSize, &resp_data,
                     &downstreamDevices);
EXPECT_EQ(rc, PLDM_ERROR_INVALID_LENGTH);
```

But I got the assert failure and the test case containtly fails.
```
libpldm_firmware_update_test: ../src/msgbuf.h:727:
pldm_msgbuf_span_required: Assertion `ctx->remaining >= 0' failed.
```

It was a little bit unexpected for me, it should work by checking the rc, I changed to use `ASSERT_DEATH` to pass the test case instead, do you have any suggestion for it?
Thanks for the explanation, however I was asking that you add the comment in the code 😊
Done
Can you please provide an explanation here?

The string compares to the error message, the code in `pldm_msgbuf_span_required` does not output any error message, so I let it be empty. [Reference](https://google.github.io/googletest/reference/assertions.html#EXPECT_DEATH)
Again, this comment would be more helpful in the code 😊
Done
Note: There is a copy patchset since the CI build was aborted.

What do you mean?

For your awareness, you can manually retrigger CI without re-pushing patches. You need to navigate to the job in jenkins.openbmc.org (usually using the build failure link in the patch comments). From there select "log in" up the top-right. Jenkins is configured to use Github authentication in the same way as this Gerrit instance, so no extra credentials are required. From there, on the menu on the left of the Jenkins UI you should see a "Retrigger" option.

Mark this comment thread as resolved if that works for you.
Hi, just a few minor comments remaining.
Yeah, I've tried and it's work, thanks for the tutorial!
This is just an `out` parameter, not `in,out`.
Done
Needs a code comment explaining why you're using `ASSERT_DEATH()` here.
Done
Empty string needs a comment in the code explaining it.
Done
Hello, just a couple of minor requests left. Thanks for iterating on the patch.
Can you mention the relationship to Table 17 as well?
Sure, the comment has been added, please let me know if you have any suggestions.
Done
This is should be `out`, not `in,out`.
Done
Hello, I'm happy to submit this. Just need the previous patch fixed.
